turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Amelia Earhart.
turn.1: Why is there a theory that Amelia Earhart crashed in the Pacific?
turn.2: To reach and land there would have required Earhart and Noonan, though low on fuel, to change her northeast course as she neared Howland Island and fly hundreds of miles northwest, a feat "not supported by the basic rules of geography and navigation." Additionally, had the Japanese found a crashed Earhart and Noonan, they would have had substantial motivation to rescue the famous aviators and be hailed as heroes.
turn.3: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.4: The unresolved circumstances of Earhart's disappearance, along with her fame, attracted a great body of other claims relating to her last flight.
turn.5: What are some of the claims?
turn.6: Several unsupported theories have become known in popular culture.
turn.7: What are some of the unsupported theories in popular culture?
turn.8: The World War II-era movie "Flight for Freedom" (1943) is a story of a fictional female aviator (obviously inspired by Earhart) who engages in a spying mission in the Pacific.
turn.9: What was the outcome of the movie?
turn.10: The movie helped further a myth that Earhart was spying on the Japanese in the Pacific at the request of the Franklin D. Roosevelt administration.
turn.11: Was there any truth to that?
turn.12: By 1949, both the United Press and U.S. Army Intelligence had concluded that this rumor was groundless.
